config.text: You're driving in town. Why should you be careful if there's a bus at a bus stop on the other side of the road?

choices.label: The bus might have broken down
Pedestrians might come from behind the bus
The bus might move off suddenly
The bus might remain stationary

correct.text: If you see a bus ahead, watch out for pedestrians. They might not be able to see you if they’re behind the bus.

incorrect.text: If you see a bus ahead, watch out for pedestrians. They might not be able to see you if they’re behind the bus.

config.text: Why do motorcyclists often look round over their right shoulder just before turning right?

choices.label: To listen for traffic behind them
Motorcycles don't have mirrors
It helps them balance as they turn
To check for traffic in their blind area

correct.text: When you see a motorcyclist take a glance over their shoulder, they're probably about to change direction. Recognising a clue like this helps you to anticipate their next action. This can improve road safety for you and others.

incorrect.text: When you see a motorcyclist take a glance over their shoulder, they're probably about to change direction. Recognising a clue like this helps you to anticipate their next action. This can improve road safety for you and others.

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: No cycling
Cycle route ahead
Cycle parking only
End of cycle route

correct.text: More people are cycling today and cycle routes are being extended in our towns and cities to provide safe cycling routes. Respect the presence of cyclists on the road and give them plenty of room if you need to pass.

incorrect.text: More people are cycling today and cycle routes are being extended in our towns and cities to provide safe cycling routes. Respect the presence of cyclists on the road and give them plenty of room if you need to pass.

config.text: How will a school crossing patrol signal you to stop?

choices.label: By pointing to children waiting to cross
By displaying a red light
By displaying a 'stop' sign
By giving you an arm signal

correct.text: If a school crossing patrol steps out into the road with a 'stop' sign, you must stop. Don’t wave anyone across the road and don’t get impatient or rev your engine.

incorrect.text: If a school crossing patrol steps out into the road with a 'stop' sign, you must stop. Don’t wave anyone across the road and don’t get impatient or rev your engine.

config.text: What should you do if you want to turn left at a junction where pedestrians have started to cross?

choices.label: Go around them, leaving plenty of room
Stop and wave at them to cross
Sound your horn and proceed
Give way to them

correct.text: When you're turning into a side road, pedestrians who are crossing have priority. You should wait to allow them to finish crossing safely. Be patient if they're slow or unsteady. Don't try to rush them by sounding your horn, flashing your lights, revving your engine or giving any other inappropriate signal.

incorrect.text: When you're turning into a side road, pedestrians who are crossing have priority. You should wait to allow them to finish crossing safely. Be patient if they're slow or unsteady. Don't try to rush them by sounding your horn, flashing your lights, revving your engine or giving any other inappropriate signal.

config.text: You want to reverse into a side road. What should you do if you aren't sure that the area behind your car is clear?

choices.label: Look through the rear window only
Get out and check
Check the mirrors only
Carry on, assuming it's clear

correct.text: If you can't tell whether there's anything behind you, it's always safest to check before reversing. There may be a small child or a low obstruction close behind your car.

incorrect.text: If you can't tell whether there's anything behind you, it's always safest to check before reversing. There may be a small child or a low obstruction close behind your car.

config.text: Why is a toucan crossing different from a puffin crossing?

choices.label: Moped riders can use it
It's controlled by a traffic warden
It's controlled by two flashing lights
Pedestrians and cyclists can use it together

correct.text: Puffin crossings are for use by pedestrians. Cyclists must dismount and push their bicycle over the crossing. Toucan crossings are shared by pedestrians and cyclists, who are permitted to cycle over the crossing. Toucan roadside signals show an icon of a pedestrian and a cyclist together.

incorrect.text: Puffin crossings are for use by pedestrians. Cyclists must dismount and push their bicycle over the crossing. Toucan crossings are shared by pedestrians and cyclists, who are permitted to cycle over the crossing. Toucan roadside signals show an icon of a pedestrian and a cyclist together.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r208, HC r238, KYTS p65

config.text: What's the purpose of these road markings?

choices.label: To ensure children can see and be seen when they're crossing the road
To enable teachers to have clear access to the school
To ensure delivery vehicles have easy access to the school
To enable parents to pick up or drop off children safely

correct.text: These markings are found on the road outside schools. Don't stop or park on them, even to set down or pick up children. The markings are there to ensure that drivers, riders, children and other pedestrians have a clear view of the road in all directions.

incorrect.text: These markings are found on the road outside schools. Don't stop or park on them, even to set down or pick up children. The markings are there to ensure that drivers, riders, children and other pedestrians have a clear view of the road in all directions.

config.text: Who may use toucan crossings?

choices.label: Motorcyclists and cyclists
Motorcyclists and pedestrians
Only cyclists
Cyclists and pedestrians

correct.text: There are some crossings where cycle routes lead cyclists to cross at the same place as pedestrians. Always look out for cyclists, as they're likely to be approaching faster than pedestrians.

incorrect.text: There are some crossings where cycle routes lead cyclists to cross at the same place as pedestrians. Always look out for cyclists, as they're likely to be approaching faster than pedestrians.

config.text: As you approach a pelican crossing, the lights change to green. What should you do if older people are still crossing?

choices.label: Wave them to cross as quickly as they can
Rev your engine to make them hurry
Flash your lights in case they haven't noticed you
Wait patiently while they cross

correct.text: If the lights turn to green, wait for any pedestrians to clear the crossing. Allow them to finish crossing the road in their own time, and don’t try to hurry them by revving your engine.

incorrect.text: If the lights turn to green, wait for any pedestrians to clear the crossing. Allow them to finish crossing the road in their own time, and don’t try to hurry them by revving your engine.

config.text: What should you do when you're approaching this crossing?

choices.label: Prepare to slow down and stop
Stop and wave the pedestrians across
Speed up and pass by quickly
Continue unless the pedestrians step out

correct.text: Be courteous and prepare to stop. Don't wave people across, because this could be dangerous if another vehicle is approaching the crossing.

incorrect.text: Be courteous and prepare to stop. Don't wave people across, because this could be dangerous if another vehicle is approaching the crossing.

config.text: At night, what does it mean if you see a pedestrian wearing reflective clothing and carrying a bright red light?

choices.label: You're approaching roadworks
You're approaching an organised walk
You're approaching a slow-moving vehicle
You're approaching a traffic danger spot

correct.text: The people on the walk should be keeping to the left, but don’t assume this. Pass carefully, making sure you have time to do so safely. Be aware that the pedestrians have their backs to you and may not know that you’re there.

incorrect.text: The people on the walk should be keeping to the left, but don’t assume this. Pass carefully, making sure you have time to do so safely. Be aware that the pedestrians have their backs to you and may not know that you’re there.

config.text: What does it mean when a moving vehicle is showing a flashing amber beacon?

choices.label: The vehicle is slow moving
The vehicle has broken down
The vehicle is a doctor's car
The vehicle belongs to a school crossing patrol

correct.text: Different coloured beacons warn of different types of vehicle needing special attention. Blue beacons are used on emergency vehicles that need priority. Green beacons are found on doctors' cars. Amber beacons generally denote slower moving vehicles, which are often large. These vehicles are usually involved in road maintenance or local amenities and make frequent stops.

incorrect.text: Different coloured beacons warn of different types of vehicle needing special attention. Blue beacons are used on emergency vehicles that need priority. Green beacons are found on doctors' cars. Amber beacons generally denote slower moving vehicles, which are often large. These vehicles are usually involved in road maintenance or local amenities and make frequent stops.

config.text: You're driving in a slow-moving queue of traffic. What should you do just before changing lane?

choices.label: Sound the horn and flash your lights
Look for motorcyclists filtering through the traffic
Give a ‘slowing down’ arm signal
Change down to first gear

correct.text: In queuing traffic, motorcyclists could be passing you on either side. Use your mirrors and check your blind area before changing lanes or changing direction.

incorrect.text: In queuing traffic, motorcyclists could be passing you on either side. Use your mirrors and check your blind area before changing lanes or changing direction.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r238, KYTS p65

config.text: Why should these road markings be kept clear?

choices.label: To allow children to be dropped off at school
To allow teachers to park
To allow children to be picked up after school
To allow children to see and be seen when they're crossing the road

correct.text:
The markings are there to show that the area should be kept clear. This is to allow an unrestricted view for
  • approaching drivers and riders
  • children wanting to cross the road.

incorrect.text:
The markings are there to show that the area should be kept clear. This is to allow an unrestricted view for
  • approaching drivers and riders
  • children wanting to cross the road.

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: Contraflow cycle lane
With-flow cycle lane
Cycles and buses only
No cycles or buses

correct.text: Usually, a picture of a cycle will also be painted on the road, and sometimes the lane will have a different coloured surface. Leave these areas clear for cyclists and don't pass too closely when you overtake.

incorrect.text: Usually, a picture of a cycle will also be painted on the road, and sometimes the lane will have a different coloured surface. Leave these areas clear for cyclists and don't pass too closely when you overtake.

config.text: What should you do when you're following a motorcyclist along a road that has a poor surface?

choices.label: Follow closely so they can see you in their mirrors
Overtake immediately to avoid delays
Allow extra room in case they swerve to avoid potholes
Allow the same room as normal to avoid wasting road space

correct.text: To avoid being unbalanced, a motorcyclist might swerve to avoid potholes and bumps in the road. Be prepared for this and allow them extra space.

incorrect.text: To avoid being unbalanced, a motorcyclist might swerve to avoid potholes and bumps in the road. Be prepared for this and allow them extra space.

config.text: What should you do when you see these horse riders in front?

choices.label: Pull out to the middle of the road
Slow down and be ready to stop
Switch on your hazard warning lights
Give a right-turn signal

correct.text: Be particularly careful when approaching horse riders – slow down and be prepared to stop. Always pass wide and slowly, and look out for signals given by the riders. Horses are unpredictable: always treat them as potential hazards and take great care when passing them.

incorrect.text: Be particularly careful when approaching horse riders – slow down and be prepared to stop. Always pass wide and slowly, and look out for signals given by the riders. Horses are unpredictable: always treat them as potential hazards and take great care when passing them.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, HC r195, HC r207

config.text: You're driving towards a zebra crossing. What should you do if a person in a wheelchair is waiting to cross?

choices.label: Continue on your way
Wave to the person to cross
Wave to the person to wait
Be prepared to stop

correct.text: You should slow down and be prepared to stop, as you would for an able-bodied person. Don’t wave them across, as other traffic may not stop.

incorrect.text: You should slow down and be prepared to stop, as you would for an able-bodied person. Don’t wave them across, as other traffic may not stop.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, HC r215

config.text: How should you overtake horse riders?

choices.label: Drive up close and overtake as soon as possible
Speed isn't important but allow plenty of room
Use your horn just once to warn them
Drive slowly and leave plenty of room

correct.text: When you decide to overtake a horse rider, make sure you can do so safely before you move out. Leave them plenty of room and pass slowly. Passing too close could startle the horse and unseat the rider.

incorrect.text: When you decide to overtake a horse rider, make sure you can do so safely before you move out. Leave them plenty of room and pass slowly. Passing too close could startle the horse and unseat the rider.

config.text: You're travelling on a narrow section of road. What should you do if a horse rider ahead is riding in the centre of the lane?

choices.label: Sound your horn to alert them to your presence
Stay behind and allow them to ride in this position
Move across to the right and try to ease past them
Get up close behind to encourage them to move aside

correct.text: On narrow sections of road, horse riders may ride in the centre of the lane. This is for their own safety as it makes them more visible. You should be patient and only pass when it's safe to do so.

incorrect.text: On narrow sections of road, horse riders may ride in the centre of the lane. This is for their own safety as it makes them more visible. You should be patient and only pass when it's safe to do so.

config.text: What does it mean if you see a pedestrian with a dog that has a yellow or burgundy coat?

choices.label: The pedestrian is an older person
The pedestrian is a dog trainer
The pedestrian is colour-blind
The pedestrian is deaf

correct.text: Dogs trained to help deaf people have a yellow or burgundy coat. If you see one, you should take extra care, as the pedestrian may not be aware of vehicles approaching.

incorrect.text: Dogs trained to help deaf people have a yellow or burgundy coat. If you see one, you should take extra care, as the pedestrian may not be aware of vehicles approaching.

config.text: Which road users are most difficult to see when you're reversing your car?

choices.label: Motorcyclists
Car drivers
Cyclists
Children

correct.text: It may not be possible to see a small child through the rear windscreen of your vehicle. Be aware of this before you reverse. If there are children about, get out and check that it's clear before reversing.

incorrect.text: It may not be possible to see a small child through the rear windscreen of your vehicle. Be aware of this before you reverse. If there are children about, get out and check that it's clear before reversing.

config.text: You're driving past parked cars. What should you do if you see a bicycle wheel sticking out between the cars?

choices.label: Accelerate past quickly and sound your horn
Slow down and wave the cyclist across
Brake sharply and flash your headlights
Slow down and be prepared to stop for a cyclist

correct.text: Scan the road as you drive. Try to anticipate hazards by being aware of the places where they're likely to occur. You’ll then be able to react in good time.

incorrect.text: Scan the road as you drive. Try to anticipate hazards by being aware of the places where they're likely to occur. You’ll then be able to react in good time.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, HC r212

config.text: You're about to overtake a cyclist. Why should you leave them as much room as you would give to a car?

choices.label: The cyclist might speed up
The cyclist might get off their bicycle
The cyclist might be unsettled if you pass too near them
The cyclist might have to make a left turn

correct.text: Before overtaking, assess the situation. Look well ahead to see whether the cyclist will need to change direction. Be especially aware of a cyclist approaching parked vehicles, as they'll need to alter course. Don't pass too closely or cut in sharply as this could unsettle the rider.

incorrect.text: Before overtaking, assess the situation. Look well ahead to see whether the cyclist will need to change direction. Be especially aware of a cyclist approaching parked vehicles, as they'll need to alter course. Don't pass too closely or cut in sharply as this could unsettle the rider.

config.text: You've driven up to a pelican crossing. What must you do while the amber light is flashing?

choices.label: Signal the pedestrian to cross
Always wait for the green light before proceeding
Give way to any pedestrians on the crossing
Wait for the red-and-amber light before proceeding

correct.text: The flashing amber light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side before a green light shows to the traffic. Be aware that some pedestrians, such as older people and young children, need longer to cross. Let them do this at their own pace.

incorrect.text: The flashing amber light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side before a green light shows to the traffic. Be aware that some pedestrians, such as older people and young children, need longer to cross. Let them do this at their own pace.

config.text: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and can be hard to see. What must they display if they're travelling on a dual carriageway?

choices.label: Flashing red beacon
Flashing green beacon
Flashing blue beacon
Flashing amber beacon

correct.text: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and low making them hard to see on the road. They also travel very slowly. On an unrestricted dual carriageway, they must display a flashing amber beacon to warn other road users of their presence.

incorrect.text: Powered vehicles used by disabled people are small and low making them hard to see on the road. They also travel very slowly. On an unrestricted dual carriageway, they must display a flashing amber beacon to warn other road users of their presence.

meta.xref: HC rH2, HC r170, HC r206

config.text: You're turning right from a main road into a side road. There's no oncoming traffic. What should you do if pedestrians are standing on the pavement waiting to cross the side road?

choices.label: Turn in because the pedestrians are safe on the pavement
Wave at the pedestrians, inviting them to cross the road
Wait and give way to the pedestrians
Sound your horn to alert the pedestrians to your presence

correct.text: You should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross the road into which or from which you're turning. Be patient if they're cautious and take their time checking that it's safe before they step into the road.

incorrect.text: You should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross the road into which or from which you're turning. Be patient if they're cautious and take their time checking that it's safe before they step into the road.

config.text: You've stopped at a pelican crossing. What should you do if a disabled person is crossing slowly in front of you and the lights change to green?

choices.label: Wait for them to finish crossing
Drive in front of them
Edge forward slowly
Sound your horn

correct.text: At a pelican crossing, the green light means you may proceed as long as the crossing is clear. If someone hasn’t finished crossing, be patient and wait for them, whether they're disabled or not.

incorrect.text: At a pelican crossing, the green light means you may proceed as long as the crossing is clear. If someone hasn’t finished crossing, be patient and wait for them, whether they're disabled or not.

config.text: You see a pedestrian carrying a white stick that also has a red band. What does this mean?

choices.label: They have limited mobility
They're deaf
They're blind
They're deaf and blind

correct.text: When someone is deaf as well as blind, they may carry a white stick with a red reflective band or bands. They may not be aware that you're approaching and they may not be able to hear anything; so, for example, your horn would be ineffective as a warning to them.

incorrect.text: When someone is deaf as well as blind, they may carry a white stick with a red reflective band or bands. They may not be aware that you're approaching and they may not be able to hear anything; so, for example, your horn would be ineffective as a warning to them.

config.text: Where would you see this sign?

choices.label: In the window of a car taking children to school
At the side of the road
At playground areas
On the rear of a school bus or coach

correct.text: Vehicles that are used to carry children to and from school will be travelling at busy times of the day. If you're following a vehicle with this sign, be prepared for it to make frequent stops. It might pick up or set down passengers in places other than normal bus stops.

incorrect.text: Vehicles that are used to carry children to and from school will be travelling at busy times of the day. If you're following a vehicle with this sign, be prepared for it to make frequent stops. It might pick up or set down passengers in places other than normal bus stops.

config.text: You see a horse rider as you approach a roundabout. What should you do if they're signalling right but keeping well to the left?

choices.label: Proceed as normal
Keep close to them
Cut in front of them
Stay well back

correct.text: Allow the horse rider to enter and exit the roundabout in their own time. They may feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Don’t get up close behind or alongside them, because that would probably upset the horse and create a dangerous situation.

incorrect.text: Allow the horse rider to enter and exit the roundabout in their own time. They may feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Don’t get up close behind or alongside them, because that would probably upset the horse and create a dangerous situation.

config.text: You're at the front of a queue of traffic waiting to turn right into a side road. Why is it important to check your right mirror just before turning?

choices.label: To look for pedestrians about to cross
To check for overtaking vehicles
To make sure the side road is clear
To check for emerging traffic

correct.text: A motorcyclist could be riding along the outside of the queue. Always check your mirror before turning, as situations behind you can change while you've been waiting to turn.

incorrect.text: A motorcyclist could be riding along the outside of the queue. Always check your mirror before turning, as situations behind you can change while you've been waiting to turn.

config.text: What hazard should you be especially aware of if you're turning left into a side road?

choices.label: One-way street
Pedestrians
Traffic congestion
Parked vehicles

correct.text: Make sure that you've reduced your speed and are in the correct gear for the turn. Look into the road before you turn and always give way to any pedestrians who are crossing.

incorrect.text: Make sure that you've reduced your speed and are in the correct gear for the turn. Look into the road before you turn and always give way to any pedestrians who are crossing.

config.text: You want to turn right from a main road into a side road. What should you do just before turning?

choices.label: Cancel your right-turn signal
Select first gear
Check for traffic overtaking on your right
Stop and set the parking brake

correct.text: In some circumstances, your indicators may be difficult to see and another road user may not realise you're about to turn. A final check in your mirror and blind spot can help you to see an overtaking vehicle, so that you can avoid turning across their path.

incorrect.text: In some circumstances, your indicators may be difficult to see and another road user may not realise you're about to turn. A final check in your mirror and blind spot can help you to see an overtaking vehicle, so that you can avoid turning across their path.

config.text: You're driving at night. What should you do if you're dazzled by a vehicle behind you?

choices.label: Set your mirror to the anti-dazzle position
Set your mirror to dazzle the other driver
Brake sharply to a stop
Switch your rear lights on and off

correct.text: The interior mirror of most vehicles can be set to an anti-dazzle position. You'll still be able to see the lights of the traffic behind you, but the dazzle will be greatly reduced.

incorrect.text: The interior mirror of most vehicles can be set to an anti-dazzle position. You'll still be able to see the lights of the traffic behind you, but the dazzle will be greatly reduced.

config.text: Why do motorcyclists use dipped headlights in daylight?

choices.label: So that the rider can be seen more easily
To stop the battery overcharging
To improve the rider’s vision
The rider is inviting you to proceed

correct.text: A motorcycle can be lost from sight behind another vehicle. The use of headlights helps to make it more conspicuous and therefore more easily seen.

incorrect.text: A motorcycle can be lost from sight behind another vehicle. The use of headlights helps to make it more conspicuous and therefore more easily seen.

config.text: What should you do when you see an older person about to cross the road ahead?

choices.label: Expect them to wait for you to pass
Speed up to get past them quickly
Stop and wave them across the road
Be careful; they may misjudge your speed

correct.text: Older people may have impaired hearing, vision, concentration and judgement. They may also walk slowly and so could take a long time to cross the road.

incorrect.text: Older people may have impaired hearing, vision, concentration and judgement. They may also walk slowly and so could take a long time to cross the road.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r238, KYTS p65

config.text: The road outside this school is marked with yellow zigzag lines. What do these lines mean?

choices.label: You may park on the lines when dropping off schoolchildren
You may park on the lines when picking up schoolchildren
You shouldn't wait or park your vehicle here
You must stay with your vehicle if you park here

correct.text: Parking here would block other road users' view of the school entrance and would endanger the lives of children on their way to and from school.

incorrect.text: Parking here would block other road users' view of the school entrance and would endanger the lives of children on their way to and from school.

config.text: How should you react to inexperienced drivers?

choices.label: Sound your horn to warn them of your presence
Be patient and prepare for them to react more slowly
Flash your headlights to indicate that it's safe for them to proceed
Overtake them as soon as possible

correct.text: Learners might not have confidence when they first start to drive. Allow them plenty of room and don’t react adversely to their hesitation. We all learn from experience, but new drivers will have had less practice in dealing with all the situations that might occur.

incorrect.text: Learners might not have confidence when they first start to drive. Allow them plenty of room and don’t react adversely to their hesitation. We all learn from experience, but new drivers will have had less practice in dealing with all the situations that might occur.

meta.xref: DES s8, DES s10, HC r207, HC r211

config.text: Which is the most vulnerable road user?

choices.label: Car driver
Tractor driver
Lorry driver
Motorcyclist

correct.text: Pedestrians and riders on two wheels can be harder to see than other road users. Make sure you look for them, especially at junctions. Effective observation, coupled with appropriate action, can save lives.

incorrect.text: Pedestrians and riders on two wheels can be harder to see than other road users. Make sure you look for them, especially at junctions. Effective observation, coupled with appropriate action, can save lives.

config.text: You're on a country road. What should you expect to see coming towards you on your side of the road?

choices.label: Motorcycles
Bicycles
Pedestrians
Horse riders

correct.text: On a quiet country road, always be aware that there may be a hazard just around the next bend, such as a slow-moving vehicle or pedestrians. Pedestrians are advised to walk on the right-hand side of the road if there's no pavement, so they may be walking towards you on your side of the road.

incorrect.text: On a quiet country road, always be aware that there may be a hazard just around the next bend, such as a slow-moving vehicle or pedestrians. Pedestrians are advised to walk on the right-hand side of the road if there's no pavement, so they may be walking towards you on your side of the road.

config.text: You've just passed your driving test. How can you reduce your risk of being involved in a collision?

choices.label: By always staying close to the vehicle in front
By never going over 40 mph
By staying in the left-hand lane on all roads
By taking further training

correct.text: New drivers and riders are often involved in a collision or incident early in their driving career. Due to a lack of experience, they may not react to hazards appropriately. Approved training courses are offered by driver and rider training schools for people who have passed their test but want extra training.

incorrect.text: New drivers and riders are often involved in a collision or incident early in their driving career. Due to a lack of experience, they may not react to hazards appropriately. Approved training courses are offered by driver and rider training schools for people who have passed their test but want extra training.

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: No route for pedestrians and cyclists
A route for pedestrians only
A route for cyclists only
A route for pedestrians and cyclists

correct.text: This sign shows a shared route for pedestrians and cyclists: when it ends, the cyclists will be rejoining the main road.

incorrect.text: This sign shows a shared route for pedestrians and cyclists: when it ends, the cyclists will be rejoining the main road.

meta.xref: DES s8, DES s10, HC r79, HC r186

config.text: You're following two cyclists as they approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane. Where would you expect the cyclists to go?

choices.label: Left
Right
Any direction
Straight ahead

correct.text: Cyclists approaching a roundabout in the left-hand lane may be turning right but may not have been able to get into the correct lane due to heavy traffic. They may also feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Be aware of them and give them plenty of room.

incorrect.text: Cyclists approaching a roundabout in the left-hand lane may be turning right but may not have been able to get into the correct lane due to heavy traffic. They may also feel safer keeping to the left all the way around the roundabout. Be aware of them and give them plenty of room.

config.text: Where would you see this sign?

choices.label: Near a school crossing
At a playground entrance
On a school bus
At a 'pedestrians only' area

correct.text: School buses can stop to pick up or drop off schoolchildren at places that aren't designated bus stops. Watch out for children crossing the road to catch the bus or from the far side of the bus if they've just been dropped off.

incorrect.text: School buses can stop to pick up or drop off schoolchildren at places that aren't designated bus stops. Watch out for children crossing the road to catch the bus or from the far side of the bus if they've just been dropped off.

meta.xref: DES s8, HC r182, HC r211

config.text: You're travelling behind a moped. What should you do if you want to turn left a short distance ahead?

choices.label: Overtake the moped before the junction
Pull alongside the moped and stay level until just before the junction
Sound your horn as a warning and pull in front of the moped
Stay behind until the moped has passed the junction

correct.text: Passing the moped and turning into the junction could mean that you cut across the front of the rider. This might force them to slow down, stop or even lose control. Stay behind the moped until it has passed the junction and then you can turn without affecting the rider.

incorrect.text: Passing the moped and turning into the junction could mean that you cut across the front of the rider. This might force them to slow down, stop or even lose control. Stay behind the moped until it has passed the junction and then you can turn without affecting the rider.

config.text: Why should you check for motorcyclists just before turning right into a side road?

choices.label: They may be overtaking on your left
They may be following you closely
They may be emerging from the side road
They may be overtaking on your right

correct.text: Never attempt to change direction to the right without first checking your right-hand mirror and blind spot. A motorcyclist might not have seen your signal and could be hidden by other traffic. This observation should become a matter of routine.

incorrect.text: Never attempt to change direction to the right without first checking your right-hand mirror and blind spot. A motorcyclist might not have seen your signal and could be hidden by other traffic. This observation should become a matter of routine.

meta.xref: DES s6, DES s10, HC r208

config.text: What action should you take when you see flashing amber lights under a school warning sign?

choices.label: Reduce speed until you're clear of the area
Keep up your speed and sound the horn
Increase your speed to clear the area quickly
Wait at the lights until they stop flashing

correct.text: The flashing amber lights are switched on to warn you that children may be crossing near a school. Slow down and take extra care, as you may have to stop.

incorrect.text: The flashing amber lights are switched on to warn you that children may be crossing near a school. Slow down and take extra care, as you may have to stop.

config.text: Why should you allow extra room while overtaking a motorcyclist on a windy day?

choices.label: The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind
The rider may be blown in front of you
The rider may stop suddenly
The rider may be travelling faster than normal

correct.text: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might make a motorcyclist (or cyclist) swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

incorrect.text: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might make a motorcyclist (or cyclist) swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

meta.xref: HC rH2, HC r170, HC r206

config.text: You're turning left from a main road into a side road. What should you do if there's a pedestrian on the pavement waiting to cross the side road?

choices.label: Flash your lights to encourage the pedestrian to cross
Carry on turning into the side road
Sound your horn to let the pedestrian know you're there
Wait and give way to the pedestrian

correct.text: You should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross the road into which or from which you're turning. Be patient if they're cautious, and let them check that it's safe from all directions before they step into the road. Do not signal or wave them to cross.

incorrect.text: You should give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross the road into which or from which you're turning. Be patient if they're cautious, and let them check that it's safe from all directions before they step into the road. Do not signal or wave them to cross.

config.text: You're following a cyclist. What should you do when you wish to turn left a short distance ahead?

choices.label: Overtake the cyclist before you reach the junction
Pull alongside the cyclist and stay level until after the junction
Hold back until the cyclist has passed the junction
Go around the cyclist on the junction

correct.text: Make allowances for cyclists, and give them plenty of room. Don’t overtake and then immediately turn left. Be patient and turn behind them when they've passed the junction.

incorrect.text: Make allowances for cyclists, and give them plenty of room. Don’t overtake and then immediately turn left. Be patient and turn behind them when they've passed the junction.

config.text: Which sign means that there may be people walking along the road?

correct.text: Always check the road signs. Triangular signs are warning signs: they inform you about hazards ahead and help you to anticipate any problems. There are a number of different signs showing pedestrians. Learn the meaning of each one.

incorrect.text: Always check the road signs. Triangular signs are warning signs: they inform you about hazards ahead and help you to anticipate any problems. There are a number of different signs showing pedestrians. Learn the meaning of each one.

config.text: Why should you look carefully for motorcyclists and cyclists at junctions?

choices.label: They may want to turn into the side road
They may slow down to let you turn
They're harder to see
They might not see you turn

correct.text: Cyclists and motorcyclists are smaller than other vehicles and so are more difficult to see. They can easily be hidden from your view by cars parked near a junction.

incorrect.text: Cyclists and motorcyclists are smaller than other vehicles and so are more difficult to see. They can easily be hidden from your view by cars parked near a junction.

meta.xref: DES s10, HC r186, HC r215

config.text: You're approaching a roundabout. What should you do if there are horses being ridden in front of you?

choices.label: Sound your horn as a warning
Treat them like any other vehicle
Give them plenty of room
Accelerate past as quickly as possible

correct.text: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

incorrect.text: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

config.text: Which vehicle should you allow extra room as you overtake them?

choices.label: Lorry
Tractor
Bicycle
Road-sweeper

correct.text:
Don’t pass cyclists too closely, as they may
  • need to veer around a pothole, drain or other hazard
  • be buffeted by side wind
  • be made unsteady by your vehicle.
Always leave as much room as you would for a car, and don’t cut in front of them.

incorrect.text:
Don’t pass cyclists too closely, as they may
  • need to veer around a pothole, drain or other hazard
  • be buffeted by side wind
  • be made unsteady by your vehicle.
Always leave as much room as you would for a car, and don’t cut in front of them.

config.text: Why do motorcyclists wear bright clothing?

choices.label: They must do so by law
It helps keep them cool in summer
The colours are popular
To make them more visible

correct.text: Motorcycles and scooters are generally smaller than other vehicles and can be difficult to see. Wearing bright clothing makes it easier for other road users to see a motorcyclist approaching, especially at junctions.

incorrect.text: Motorcycles and scooters are generally smaller than other vehicles and can be difficult to see. Wearing bright clothing makes it easier for other road users to see a motorcyclist approaching, especially at junctions.

config.text: This junction, controlled by traffic lights, has a marked area between two stop lines. What's this for?

choices.label: To allow taxis to position in front of other traffic
To allow people with disabilities to cross the road
To allow cyclists and pedestrians to cross the road together
To allow cyclists to position in front of other traffic

correct.text: These are known as advanced stop lines. When the lights are red (or about to become red), you should stop at the first white line. However, if you've crossed that line as the lights change, you must stop at the second line even if it means you're in the area reserved for cyclists.

incorrect.text: These are known as advanced stop lines. When the lights are red (or about to become red), you should stop at the first white line. However, if you've crossed that line as the lights change, you must stop at the second line even if it means you're in the area reserved for cyclists.

config.text: What should you do when you're following a learner driver who stalls at a junction?

choices.label: Be patient, as you expect them to make mistakes
Stay very close behind and flash your headlights
Start to rev your engine if they take too long to restart
Immediately steer around them and drive on

correct.text: Learning to drive is a process of practice and experience. Try to understand this and tolerate those who make mistakes while they're learning.

incorrect.text: Learning to drive is a process of practice and experience. Try to understand this and tolerate those who make mistakes while they're learning.

config.text: You're approaching a roundabout. What should you do if a cyclist ahead is signalling to turn right?

choices.label: Overtake on the right
Give a warning with your horn
Signal the cyclist to move across
Give the cyclist plenty of room

correct.text: If you’re following a cyclist who’s signalling to turn right at a roundabout, leave plenty of room. Give them space and time to get into the correct lane.

incorrect.text: If you’re following a cyclist who’s signalling to turn right at a roundabout, leave plenty of room. Give them space and time to get into the correct lane.

config.text: What would you do if you see older people crossing the road ahead?

choices.label: Wave them across so they know that you've seen them
Be patient and allow them to cross in their own time
Rev the engine to let them know that you're waiting
Tap the horn in case they're hard of hearing

correct.text: Be aware that older people might take a long time to cross the road. They might also be hard of hearing and not hear you approaching. Don't hurry older people across the road by getting too close to them or revving your engine.

incorrect.text: Be aware that older people might take a long time to cross the road. They might also be hard of hearing and not hear you approaching. Don't hurry older people across the road by getting too close to them or revving your engine.

meta.xref: DES s8, DES s10, HC r79, HC r186

config.text: You're approaching this roundabout. What should you do when a cyclist is keeping to the left while signalling to turn right?

choices.label: Sound your horn
Overtake them
Assume they're turning left
Allow them space to turn

correct.text: Cycling in today’s heavy traffic can be hazardous. Some cyclists may not feel safe crossing the path of traffic to take up a position in an outside lane. Be aware of this and understand that, although they're in the left-hand lane, the cyclist might be turning right.

incorrect.text: Cycling in today’s heavy traffic can be hazardous. Some cyclists may not feel safe crossing the path of traffic to take up a position in an outside lane. Be aware of this and understand that, although they're in the left-hand lane, the cyclist might be turning right.

config.text: A horse rider is in the left-hand lane approaching a roundabout. Where should you expect the rider to go?

choices.label: In any direction
To the right
To the left
Straight ahead

correct.text: Horses and their riders move more slowly than other road users. They might not have time to cut across heavy traffic to take up a position in the right-hand lane. For this reason, a horse and rider may approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane even though they're turning right.

incorrect.text: Horses and their riders move more slowly than other road users. They might not have time to cut across heavy traffic to take up a position in the right-hand lane. For this reason, a horse and rider may approach a roundabout in the left-hand lane even though they're turning right.

config.text: You're waiting to come out of a side road. Why should you look carefully for motorcycles?

choices.label: Motorcycles are usually faster than cars
Police patrols often use motorcycles
Motorcycles can easily be hidden behind obstructions
Motorcycles have right of way

correct.text: If you're waiting to emerge from a side road, look carefully for motorcycles: they can be difficult to see. Be especially careful if there are parked vehicles or other obstructions restricting your view.

incorrect.text: If you're waiting to emerge from a side road, look carefully for motorcycles: they can be difficult to see. Be especially careful if there are parked vehicles or other obstructions restricting your view.

meta.xref: DES s8, DES s10, HC r152

config.text: You want to turn right from a junction. What should you do if your view is restricted by parked vehicles?

choices.label: Move out quickly, but be prepared to stop
Sound your horn and pull out if there's no reply
Stop, then move forward slowly until you have a clear view
Stop, get out and look along the main road to check

correct.text:
If you want to turn right from a junction and your view is restricted, stop. Ease forward until you can see – something might be approaching.
If you don't know, don't go.

incorrect.text:
If you want to turn right from a junction and your view is restricted, stop. Ease forward until you can see – something might be approaching.
If you don't know, don't go.

config.text: What should you do when you're passing loose sheep on the road?

choices.label: Briefly sound your horn
Go very slowly
Pass quickly but quietly
Herd them to the side of the road

correct.text: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if you're signalled to do so by the person in charge.

incorrect.text: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if you're signalled to do so by the person in charge.

meta.xref: DES s8, DES s10, HC r170, HC r211

config.text: Where should you take particular care to look for motorcyclists and cyclists?

choices.label: On dual carriageways
At junctions
At zebra crossings
On one-way streets

correct.text: Motorcyclists and cyclists are often more difficult to see at junctions. They're easily hidden from view and you may not be able to see them approaching a junction if your view is partially blocked; for example, by other traffic.

incorrect.text: Motorcyclists and cyclists are often more difficult to see at junctions. They're easily hidden from view and you may not be able to see them approaching a junction if your view is partially blocked; for example, by other traffic.

meta.xref: DES s10, HC r2, HC r206

config.text: What should you do if the left-hand pavement is closed due to street repairs?

choices.label: Watch out for pedestrians walking in the road
Use your right-hand mirror more often
Speed up to get past the roadworks more quickly
Position close to the left-hand kerb

correct.text: Where street repairs have closed off pavements, proceed carefully and slowly, as pedestrians might have to walk in the road.

incorrect.text: Where street repairs have closed off pavements, proceed carefully and slowly, as pedestrians might have to walk in the road.

config.text: You're driving past a line of parked cars. What should you do if a ball bounces out into the road ahead?

choices.label: Continue driving at the same speed and sound your horn
Continue driving at the same speed and flash your headlights
Slow down and be prepared to stop for children
Stop and wave the children across to fetch their ball

correct.text: Beware of children playing in the street and running out into the road. If a ball bounces out from the pavement, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t encourage anyone to retrieve it. Other road users may not see your signal and you might lead a child into a dangerous situation.

incorrect.text: Beware of children playing in the street and running out into the road. If a ball bounces out from the pavement, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don’t encourage anyone to retrieve it. Other road users may not see your signal and you might lead a child into a dangerous situation.

config.text: You're about to reverse into a side road. What should you do if a pedestrian is waiting to cross behind your car?

choices.label: Wave to the pedestrian to stop
Give way to the pedestrian
Sound your horn to warn the pedestrian
Reverse before the pedestrian starts to cross

correct.text: If you need to reverse into a side road, try to find a place that’s free from traffic and pedestrians. Look all around before and during the manoeuvre. Stop and give way to any pedestrians who want to cross behind you. Avoid waving them across, sounding the horn, flashing your lights or giving any signals that could mislead them and create a dangerous situation.

incorrect.text: If you need to reverse into a side road, try to find a place that’s free from traffic and pedestrians. Look all around before and during the manoeuvre. Stop and give way to any pedestrians who want to cross behind you. Avoid waving them across, sounding the horn, flashing your lights or giving any signals that could mislead them and create a dangerous situation.

config.text: You're about to overtake a cyclist on a road that has a 30 mph speed limit. How much room should you leave them as you overtake?

choices.label: At least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car
At least a car's width
At least a car's length
At least 2 car widths

correct.text: You should leave cyclists at least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car. Leave them more room if you're overtaking at speeds over 30 mph.

incorrect.text: You should leave cyclists at least as much room as you would if you were overtaking a car. Leave them more room if you're overtaking at speeds over 30 mph.
